newsitem.title: FRANCE: Rhone-Poulenc Australia to suspend gallium output.
newsitem.headline: Rhone-Poulenc Australia to suspend gallium output.

text.p: Rhone-Poulenc Australia will next month suspend gallium extraction at its Pinjarra facility in western Australia in the face of disappointing demand, parent Rhone-Poulenc Chimie said on Monday.
Rhone-Poulenc Chimie is a division of French chemicals and pharmaceuticals group Rhone-Poulenc.
"Closing operations will start in early June and will be completed by end July," a company spokeswoman told Reuters.
In a statement the company said that after a strong growth in 1994 and 1995, gallium demand was below expectations, particularly in Japan, where it declined.
Growth in high-frequency integrated circuits did not offset lower demand for light-emitting diodes, the main market for gallium, it said.
Other applications such as gallium dental amalgams were still limited while its potential applications for industrial catalysts was not yet clear.
Rhone-Poulenc Chimie said that its stocks levels and output at its other two existing facilities of Stade, Germany, and Salindres, France, will be sufficient to meet current demand.
Annual gallium's extraction capacity at Pinjarra is 50 tonnes. Extraction's capacity at Stade is 20 tonnes and processing capacity at Salingres is of over 70 tonnes, the spokeswoman said.
She also said that the group had the expertise to restart production at Pinjarra "rather quickly" if market conditions improved.
Rhone-Poulenc started the Pinjarra plant in 1989 for an initial investment of A$50 million. But it was forced to suspend production in 1990 due to slow demand. It reopened the plant in early 1996.
